caption.body: French American coloratura soprano Lily Pons (1898â€“1976) was a pop-cultural sensation and appeared on radio programs, recorded for RCA Records, starred in Hollywood films, and had perfume, flowers, and even a townâ€”Lilypons, Marylandâ€”named after her. She graced the cover of Time magazine in October 1932, and then in December 1940 wearing the costume on exhibition, made for her role as Marie in a revival of Donizettiâ€™s ğ˜“ğ˜¢ ğ˜ğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜¦ ğ˜¥ğ˜¶ ğ˜™Ã©ğ˜¨ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜µ at the Metropolitan Opera. San Francisco Opera first performed ğ˜“ğ˜¢ ğ˜ğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜¦ ğ˜¥ğ˜¶ ğ˜™Ã©ğ˜¨ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜µ in October 1941, again starring Pons. The world was engulfed in war when the opera was staged in San Francisco the following year, and during the final scene, Pons waved the flag of Free France and led a sing-along of the French national anthem, â€œLa Marseillaise,â€ followed by the â€œStar Spangled Bannerâ€ as the French flag was dipped in tribute.   Learn more about San Francisco Operaâ€™s history in our exhibition â€œSan Francisco Opera: A Centennial Celebrationâ€ on display, post-security, in Harvey Milk Terminal 1. https://bit.ly/SFOperaCentennial
